awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for the ACM Conference on Information-Centric Networking 2019 (ACM ICN 2019)
awd_abstract_narration:
This travel grant helps fund US-based 8 students to attend the annual ACM Conference in Information-Centric Networking, September 24-26, 2019 at City University of Hong Kong, Kowloon (Hong Kong), China. This conference is the leading venue for research on the relatively new concept of Information Centric networking that gained credence as a result of the NSF's Future Internet Architecture program. Students given the opportunity to attend and participate in the conference will be exposed to and interact with the leaders in this field of research, a full program of peer-reviewed papers, poster and demonstration sessions, and social events. Exposing graduate students to the research venues and participants in the research field of their choice is a critical part of their education. These travel grants will allow them to attend. 

The best research occurs when researchers are able to interact directly, discussing and questioning each others' research. This is very effectively achieved at research conferences. Enabling students to participate fully is key to building the next generation of top-notch researchers. The more frequently they are included in the research community and able to participate in such conferences, the better prepared they will be to become full-fledged researchers. This award supports US students generally, but specifically targets women, underrepresented minorities, and students with disabilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the first year of this grant, it supported a number of students to travel from the United States to Macau to attend the ACM Information Centric Networking conference. The conference focuses on a novel architectural alternative to the current Internet, based on the observation that present-day communication is primarily about exchanging or sharing information. This subfield puts ?information? at the center of the design of a network. 

 2019, the year of the original grant, was the conference?s first year in Asia and therefore was especially important. Students play a significant role in the research topic, and encouraging them in that is especially important. The PI and review team solicited for women, under-represented minorities and the disabled community, although that was not as successful as one might hope. It argues that involving these under-represented groups must begin with encouraging students in these groups to become graduate students in the field. We should continue to try to recruit them, but other types of efforts may be more effective at broadening participation. Due to the Covid pandemic, the conference was held virtually in both 2020 and 2021. As a result, although we requested that we be allowed to use the grant funds either to support students attending the conference virtually through their registration fees or students attending other related conferences in person, both options were declined.

Modified by: Karen R Sollins
